The claim is about Earth having the longest orbital period among the listed planets. So I need to look at the "orbital period" column in the table and compare Earth's value with all others.

Saturn: 29.46 years
Neptune: 164.79 years

Jupiter: 11.86
Earth: ~0.997
Gliese 581c: ~0.0354

51 Pegasi b: ~0.0116

So, the longest orbital period is Pluto at 246.04 years, followed by Neptune, Saturn, and so on.

Earth's orbital period is about 1 year, which is much shorter than several other planets in the list, especially gas giants and outer planets like Saturn and Neptune, as well as Pluto.

Therefore, the claim that Earth has the longest orbital period is FALSE because Pluto's orbital period is longer than Earth's.
